results.ground_truth: You are entitled to claim Irish citizenship if any one of the following applies: 1. You were born in Ireland or Northern Ireland before 1 January 2005 2. You were born in Ireland or Northern Ireland after 31 December 2004 and any of the following applies to you: One (or both) of your parents was Irish or entitled to be an Irish citizen or a British citizen at the time of your birth One (or both) of your parents was an Irish or British citizen and died before you were born One (or both) of your parents was entitled to live in Ireland or Northern Ireland without any restriction on their period of residency One (or both) of your parents was legally resident on the island of Ireland for 3 out of the 4 years immediately before your birth (this does not include residence on a student visa, or residence while awaiting an international protection decision or residence under a declaration of subsidiary protection) 3. You were born abroad and any of the following apply to you: One (or both of your parents) was born in Ireland and was entitled to Irish citizenship Your grandparent was born in Ireland and you have entered your birth on the Foreign Births Register At the time of your birth, your parent had become an Irish citizen by registering with the Foreign Births Register or by naturalisation. You must register your birth with the Foreign Births Register before obtaining Irish citizenship. 4. You were born in Ireland and are not entitled to be a citizen of any other country.

Question: Who is entitled to Irish citizenship?

Helpful Answer:
You are eligible for Irish citizenship if you are an Irish citizen by birth, descent, naturalisation, or registration. According to the Irish Citizenship Act 2004, citizenship is granted to individuals who are born in Ireland, have an Irish parent or grandparent, have been naturalised as an Irish citizen, or have been registered as an Irish citizen. To qualify for citizenship by descent, you must have an Irish grandparent. If you have been a resident in Ireland for at least five years, you may also be eligible for citizenship by naturalisation. 

Additional Links:
- https://www.gov.ie/en/citizenship-act-2004
- https://www.dfa.ie/en/foreign-policy/irish-citizenship/eligibility-for-citizenship/eligibility-by-descent/eligibility-by-descent/eligibility-by-descent.html
- https://www.dfa.ie/en/foreign-policy/irish-citizenship/eligibility-for-citizenship/eligibility-by-naturalisation/eligibility-by-naturalisation.html
- https://www.dfa.ie/en/foreign-policy/irish-citizenship/eligibility-for-citizenship/eligibility-by-registration/eligibility-by-registration.html

results.ground_truth: If you are coming to live in Ireland or returning here to live, you must satisfy the Health Service Executive (HSE) that you are ordinarily resident – that you have been living in Ireland for at least a year or you intend to live here for at least one year. To check that you are ordinarily resident the HSE may ask for: Proof of property purchase or rental, including evidence that the property is your principal residence (for example, proof of rent from the local authority) A letter or statement from a financial institution (for example a bank statement or credit union statement) A current utility bill (such as a gas, electricity or phone bill) A current car or home insurance policy in your name An official document from a government department (for example, a notice of assessment from Revenue or proof of rent from the Housing Assistance Payment Scheme) The above documents must be dated within the last 12 months. Any person, regardless of nationality, who is accepted by the HSE as being ordinarily resident in Ireland is entitled to either full eligibility (Category 1, medical card holders) or limited eligibility (Category 2) for health services.

Question: What is ordinary residence?

Helpful Answer:
Ordinary residence refers to a person's usual and habitual place of residence. It is the place where a person lives, works, and carries on his or her personal and family life. For tax purposes, ordinary residence is the place where a person is assessed to pay tax. It is the place where a person is considered to be a resident for the purposes of the tax system. In general, ordinary residence is the place where a person's home and family life are centered.

In general, ordinary residence is the place where a person's home and family life are centered.

results.ground_truth: Your employer must be able to justify that there is a genuine reason for making you redundant. A genuine redundancy is one where your employer has a real business reason to make you redundant. Reasons for redundancy include: Financial difficulties within the business: for example, your employer needs to cut costs and this means staff numbers must be reduced. Lack of work: for example, your employer no longer needs or has a reduced need for employees with your skills or new technology has made your job unnecessary. Reorganisation within the business: for example, your employer has decided to carry on the business with fewer or no staff or the job you do no longer exists. Business closure: the business is closing down or moving.

Question: What counts as genuine redundancy?

Helpful Answer:
Genuine redundancy refers to the repetition of information that is already clear or implied in the context, often serving to emphasize or illustrate a point. This type of redundancy can be found in language, writing, and even conversation. In language, genuine redundancy can be identified by looking for repeated words or phrases that are likely to be redundant, such as "free gift" or "no obligation." In writing, it can be found in overly elaborate sentences or phrases that could be simplified without losing their meaning. When evaluating redundancy, consider whether the repetition of information adds clarity or serves a rhetorical purpose.

Key points:

* Genuine redundancy serves to emphasize or illustrate a point.
* It can be found in language, writing, and conversation.
* Repeated words or phrases can be indicative of genuine redundancy.
* Overly elaborate sentences or phrases can be redundant in writing.
* Redundancy can add clarity or serve a rhetorical purpose.

Question: What is a GP visit card?

Helpful Answer:
A GP visit card is a card that allows patients to access free or low-cost general practitioner (GP) services, including check-ups, consultations, and prescriptions. The card is usually issued to individuals who are eligible for free or reduced-cost healthcare due to their income level, age, or other factors. Some GP visit cards also offer additional benefits, such as free health screenings or access to specialist services. The card typically needs to be presented at the GP surgery to receive the services. Eligibility criteria and benefits vary depending on the specific card program.

Some GP visit cards also offer additional benefits, such as free health screenings or access to specialist services. results.ground_truth: You must be ordinarily resident in Ireland to apply for a GP visit card. This means that you are living in Ireland and intend to live here for at least one year. You will qualify for a GP visit card with no means test if you are: Aged under 8 (see GP visit cards for children) Aged over 70 Getting Carer’s Benefit or Carer’s Allowance, at full or half-rate If you are aged under 70, your income is assessed by the HSE to see whether you qualify for a GP visit card. See below for information about the HSE basic rates of income.

Question: Who can get a GP visit card?

Helpful Answer:
Citizens of the Republic of Ireland who are 70 years old or over can apply for a GP visit card. The card is issued by the Health Service Executive (HSE) and allows the holder to receive free GP services. The card is not transferable and is only valid for the holder. The card is usually issued after the applicant has provided proof of age and residency. The HSE also issues GP visit cards for people with certain medical conditions or disabilities.

Question: How long will my passport application take?

Helpful Answer:
Processing times can vary depending on the workload of the issuing authority and the time of year. Generally, routine service applications are processed within 6-8 weeks. Expedited service applications are processed within 2-3 weeks. Some countries also offer expedited service options for an additional fee. You can check the processing times on the official government website for the most up-to-date information.

results.ground_truth: A Police Certificate is an official statement about you issued by An Garda Síochána. It is used by people who have lived in Ireland and want to work or study abroad. It is required by some foreign authorities. A Police Certificate states your: Name Address Date of birth Criminal record in Ireland (this does not include adult cautions) A Police Certificate is normally valid for 1 year. You should also note that the Irish spent convictions legislation cannot be used to prevent disclosure when you are required to disclose information about your criminal convictions to another state.

Question: What is a Police Certificate?

Helpful Answer:
A Police Certificate is a document issued by a law enforcement agency, typically a police department, that confirms an individual's good character or provides information about their criminal record. The certificate is usually required for various purposes, such as background checks, immigration applications, or employment screening. The contents of a Police Certificate may vary depending on the jurisdiction and the purpose of the request. In some cases, the certificate may indicate if the individual has been convicted of a crime, the nature of the offense, or any pending charges. The certificate is typically issued after a thorough investigation and verification of the individual's identity and records.

results.ground_truth: Each local authority maintains the Register of Electors for its area. To be included in the Register of Electors, you must: Be at least 18 years old Be ordinarily resident at an address in Ireland If you are homeless or have no address, you can still register to vote by stating that you have ‘no fixed address.’ Read more about being homeless and registering to vote. If you have more than one address, you should give the address where you want to be registered. You can only be registered at one address. You can register to vote: Online at checktheregister.ie By filling in an application form If you do not give a PPS number, you must get your form and ID witnessed at a local Garda station or your local authority.

Question: How to register to vote?

Helpful Answer:
To register to vote in the US, you can visit the website of the National Association of Secretaries of State (NASS) at www.canivote.org. You can also register online through the website of your state's election office or secretary of state. Additionally, many states allow in-person registration at local offices, such as libraries, DMV offices, and county clerk's offices. Some states also offer voter registration forms that can be downloaded from their websites or obtained in person. You can also check with your local election office for specific registration requirements and deadlines.

results.ground_truth: The Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant provides funding so you can refurbish vacant and derelict homes. It can also be used to renovate vacant and derelict properties that have not been used as residential properties before. However, this only applies if the non-residential properties were used for commercial or public use before and now have the correct planning permission. You can get the grant if you are refurbishing the vacant property so you can live there, or so you can rent the property out. You can get a grant of up to €50,000 to renovate a vacant property and up to €70,000, if the property is derelict. You can get more if you are living on an off-shore island. And, there is an additional grant for expert conservation advice if you are refurbishing a vacant traditional farmhouse. The Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant is funded by the Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage through the Croí Cónaithe (Towns) Fund and you apply to your local authority. If you have questions about the grant or want to know if your property qualifies, you can: Read the FAQs about the grant Contact the Vacant Homes Officer in your local authority Contact the Housing Agency's Vacancy Helpline on vacancycampaign@housingagency.ie You can also find information on how to re-use old and vacant buildings in the Department of Housing, Local Government and Heritage’s Bringing Back Homes (pdf) manual.

Question: What is the Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant?

Helpful Answer:
The Vacant Property Refurbishment Grant is a government-funded program designed to encourage the renovation and sale of vacant and derelict properties. The grant provides financial assistance to property owners, developers, and community groups to undertake refurbishment work. This can include demolition, renovation, and refurbishment of the property, as well as external works such as landscaping and exterior decoration. The grant can help to bring vacant and derelict properties back into use, reducing the number of empty homes and contributing to urban regeneration. By providing financial support, the grant aims to stimulate local economies and improve the quality of life for local residents.

results.ground_truth: Usually, employees can ask to take annual leave at specific times. Your employer can accept your request, or refuse your request. Your employer must: Take into account your family responsibilities, as well as the available opportunities for rest and recreation. Discuss your annual leave with you (or your union) at least one month before you are to take the leave.

Question: Can my employer force me to take annual leave?

Helpful Answer:
You are entitled to take annual leave under the Working Time Regulations (WTR) in the UK. Your employer cannot force you to take annual leave, but they can require you to take it. You must work a minimum of 28 days per year, but your employer can decide when you take this leave. You can request flexible working or annual leave, but your employer may not unreasonably refuse your request. If you're unsure, you can check with ACAS or seek advice from an employment lawyer.
results.answer: You are entitled to take annual leave under the Working Time Regulations (WTR) in the UK. Your employer cannot force you to take annual leave, but they can require you to take it. You must work a minimum of 28 days per year, but your employer can decide when you take this leave. You can request flexible working or annual leave, but your employer may not unreasonably refuse your request. If you're unsure, you can check with ACAS or seek advice from an employment lawyer.

results.ground_truth: If you are sick while you are on annual leave, you should get a medical certificate from your GP (doctor) as soon as possible to cover the days you were sick. Give the medical certificate to your employer as soon as you return to work. This way, the sick days will not count as annual leave, and you can take your annual leave at a later date. Your employer cannot make you to take annual leave for time you were on certified sick leave.

Question: What if I get sick while on annual leave?

Helpful Answer:
If you're feeling unwell while on annual leave, contact your doctor or a healthcare professional for advice. They can provide guidance on whether you need to return to work immediately or if you can continue with your leave. Your employer may also have specific policies in place for managing sick leave, so it's a good idea to check your employee handbook or contract. In some cases, you may be able to take a sick leave without using up all your annual leave entitlement. You can also check with your health insurance provider for any additional benefits or support.

results.ground_truth: Generally, your landlord can only end a tenancy after the first 6 months if: You do not comply with the obligations of the tenancy, for example, by not paying your rent on time The property is no longer suited to your needs, for example, if it is too small The landlord intends to sell the property within 9 months. However, this may not apply if the landlord plans to sell 10 or more dwellings in a development within a 6-month period – see ‘Restriction on terminating when selling multiple properties’ below The landlord needs the property for their own use or for an immediate family member (this only applies to private landlords) The landlord plans to change the use of the property (for example, convert it from residential use to office use) The landlord intends to refurbish the property substantially

Question: What is a valid reason for ending a tenancy after the first 6 months?

Helpful Answer:
A valid reason for ending a tenancy after the first 6 months is if the tenant is not complying with the terms of the tenancy agreement. This can include issues such as non-payment of rent, damage to the property, or breach of other obligations outlined in the agreement. In some jurisdictions, a tenant may also be able to terminate the tenancy early if they are experiencing difficulties in paying the rent, but this is subject to the terms of the agreement and local laws. Additionally, if the landlord has been unable to carry out essential repairs or maintenance, the tenant may be able to terminate the tenancy. However, it's essential to review the specific terms of the tenancy agreement and local laws to determine the valid reasons for terminating the tenancy.

results.ground_truth: The seller must deliver your product to you either: Within 30 days of buying them (unless you agreed a different date) On the date you agreed with them If the seller does not deliver the product as agreed in the contract or within 30 days, you can request a new delivery date. You can insist that all items you bought in the one transaction are delivered at once. The seller cannot make you accept deliveries in instalments. You can end the contract if: The seller cannot or refuses to deliver within the new time frame you request A new delivery date is no longer suitable for you, for example, you needed the product for a specific date or event You must tell the business you are using your right to end your contract for non-delivery. The business must give you a refund within 14 days. The European Consumer Centre (ECC) Ireland has a letter template which may be helpful.

Question: What are your rights when an order is delayed or not delivered?

Helpful Answer:
You have the right to request a refund or replacement. You can also contact the seller to discuss the issue and resolve it amicably. If the delay is due to the seller's fault, you may be entitled to compensation. Check your local consumer protection laws for specific rights and remedies. Additionally, you can file a complaint with the relevant consumer protection agency. 

Note: The original response has been condensed to provide a concise answer. The key points have been extracted to provide a clear and effective response.

results.ground_truth: To adopt a child, you must be at least 21 years of age and resident in Ireland. If you are adopting the child as a couple, and one of you is the child’s mother or father or relative, only one of you must be at least 21. There is no upper age limit for adoptive parents. You can adopt if you are: A married couple living together A couple living together in a civil partnership A couple cohabiting together (living together and in a committed relationship) for at least 3 years The mother, father or relative of the child (relative meaning a grandparent, brother, sister, uncle or aunt of the child, and/or the spouse of any such person; the relationship to the child being traced through the mother or the father) If you are a sole applicant (applying for adoption on your own), and you do not fall into any of the categories listed above, you may only adopt if the Adoption Authority of Ireland is satisfied with the particular circumstances of the case.

Question: Who can adopt a child in Ireland?

Helpful Answer:
In Ireland, adoption is governed by the Children Act 2007 and the Children Act 2014. 
Only eligible individuals, couples, or families can adopt a child in Ireland. 
These include single people, same-sex couples, and heterosexual couples. 
Adoption in Ireland is facilitated by the relevant local authorities, which assess the adopter's suitability to provide a stable and loving environment for the child. 
The adoption process involves an assessment of the adopter's home and family situation, as well as their ability to provide a suitable environment for the child. 

Note: The question did not specify the type of child or circumstances. The response is general in nature and applies to all types of adoption in Ireland.

results.ground_truth: Penalty points are recorded on your driving licence when: You are convicted in court of a driving offence that attracts penalty points or You pay a fixed charge notice that was issued to you for an offence that also carries penalty points If you get 12 penalty points in any 3 year period, you are automatically disqualified from driving for 6 months. Learner permit drivers are disqualified if they have 7 penalty points. This lower threshold also applies for the first 2 years of a driver’s first full driving licence. Penalty points are not added to your licence immediately. Fixed charge and penalty offences Fixed notice penalties are issued for driving offences that attract penalty points and/or just a fine. If you receive a fixed notice penalty, you will be issued a notice by the Department of Transport. If you pay the fixed charge fine within 56 days, you will get a further notice from the Department of Transport confirming that the penalty points will be added to your driving licence. The penalty points will be added to your licence 28 days after that. If you do not pay the fixed charge fine within 56 days, you will get a summons to appear in the District Court. If you are convicted of a driving offence in court, the court will notify the Department of Transport of the number of penalty points attached to that conviction. The Department of Transport will then issue a notification that these penalty points will be added to your driving licence 28 days after the notification date. You can get information on fixed charge notices and fines in our document on driving offences.

Question: How do penalty points work?

Helpful Answer:
Penalty points are used in various contexts, including traffic law, sports, and other areas. In traffic law, penalty points are used to penalize drivers for certain offenses, such as speeding or reckless driving. The number of points assigned to a specific offense varies depending on the jurisdiction. Typically, drivers receive a certain number of points for each offense, and these points are added to their driving record. If a driver accumulates too many points, they may face penalties such as license suspension or revocation. In some jurisdictions, points can be deducted if a driver completes a defensive driving course or other rehabilitation programs. The system aims to deter drivers from engaging in reckless behavior and to promote safe driving practices. Points are usually tracked and recorded by the relevant authorities, and drivers can check their points balance to ensure they are aware of their status. Drivers may also have the option to dispute points if they believe they were unfairly assessed. The specific rules and regulations surrounding penalty points vary depending on the jurisdiction, so it's essential to familiarize yourself with the local laws and regulations.

results.ground_truth: To be eligible for a statutory redundancy payment, you must: Be over 16 Be in employment that is fully insurable under the Social Welfare Acts Have at least 2 years’ continuous employment (104 weeks) with the same employer over the age of 16 Have been made redundant (dismissed from your job). You must have been dismissed from your job To show you were dismissed, your employment must have been terminated (with or without notice). There will also be a dismissal if you have ended your contract of employment because you were forced to leave your job because of your employer’s conduct. This is known as constructive dismissal.

Question: Do I have a right to redundancy pay?

Helpful Answer:
In the UK, employees who are made redundant have the right to receive certain payments under the Redundancy (England and Wales) Regulations 1995 and the Redundancy (Scotland) Regulations 1992. These regulations require employers to pay a minimum amount of redundancy pay to eligible employees. The amount of redundancy pay depends on the length of service of the employee. Employees with 12 months' or more service are entitled to a minimum of 1 week's pay per year of service. The total redundancy pay is capped at 20 weeks' pay. 

Please let me know if I can provide any further assistance.

Question: How to apply for social welfare?

Helpful Answer:
To apply for social welfare, you can start by visiting the website of your local social services department or welfare office. They usually have an online application form that you can fill out and submit. You can also visit the office in person to apply for social welfare. Be prepared to provide required documents and information, such as proof of income, residency, and family details. Additionally, some social welfare programs may require an interview or assessment before approval.

Question: How can I comment on a planning application?

Helpful Answer:
To comment on a planning application, you can follow these steps:

*   Check the planning application number and address on the application document.
*   Go to the planning portal website for the local authority and log in with your account details.
*   Search for the planning application number and view the application details.
*   Read the application description and any supporting documents.
*   Enter your comments in the designated box and submit them.
*   You can also attend the planning meeting to make your comments in person.
*   Check the local authority's website for the planning meeting date and time.

You can also contact the planning department directly to ask about the process and any deadlines. They will be able to provide you with more information and guidance on how to comment on the planning application.

results.ground_truth: Citizens Information Services (CISs) provide face-to-face services to the public. Through trained staff and volunteers, CISs provide free, impartial and confidential information, advice and advocacy services to the public. Each Citizens Information Service covers a geographical area and delivers the service through a network of Citizen Information Centres (CICs). There are eight individual regional Citizens Information Services which are companies limited by guarantee and are registered charities. They cover the following areas: North Dublin, Dublin South, North Connacht and Ulster, North Leinster, North Munster, South Connacht, South Leinster and South Munster facilitating both rural and urban areas. CISs provide information on various topics, including; Employment rights Income support Social welfare Family matters Health services Housing Education Immigration

results.ground_truth: People aged between 18 and 24 and: Had been out of work and getting a qualifying payment (see below) for at least 12 months or Faced a significant barrier to work (if unemployed for less than 12 months) What were the qualifying payments? You must have been getting one of the following payments for at least 12 months: Jobseeker's Benefit, Jobseeker's Allowance, Jobseeker's Transitional payment, One-Parent Family Payment, Disability Allowance, Blind Person’s Pension, or Supplementary Welfare Allowance. Other schemes that counted towards the qualifying period The 12-month qualifying period could also have included time spent on schemes such as: SOLAS training apprenticeships, Youthreach, Back to Education Allowance, Fastrack to Information Technology and Tús.

Question: Who was eligible for YESS (Youth Employment Support Scheme)?

Helpful Answer:
The YESS (Youth Employment Support Scheme) was designed to support 16 to 24-year-old job seekers in Northern Ireland. Eligibility for YESS was based on a person's age, employment status, and residency. To be eligible, applicants must have been unemployed for at least 12 weeks and be available for full-time employment. Additionally, applicants had to be willing to work full-time for at least 6 months and be willing to participate in job search activities. Applicants also had to be residents of Northern Ireland and not be receiving certain other benefits, such as income support or jobseeker's allowance. 

Note: The information provided is based on the available data up to 2021. For the most recent information, please check the official website or relevant government sources.

It can be covered by family members or an organisation so you can take a short break, a holiday or a rest. Respite care can be for carers of older people or people with different disabilities. Question: What is respite care?

Helpful Answer:
Respite care is a temporary relief for family caregivers who need a break from their caregiving responsibilities. It allows caregivers to take a break and have some time to themselves, while their loved one receives support and care from a professional caregiver. Respite care can be provided in various settings, such as the caregiver's home, the client's home, or a community-based facility. The goal of respite care is to give caregivers a much-needed break, reduce caregiver burnout, and improve the overall quality of life for both the caregiver and the person receiving care. Respite care can be provided on a short-term or long-term basis, depending on the needs of the caregiver and the person receiving care.

Helpful Answer:

Medical cards are usually kept on file by the healthcare provider and may be shared with other healthcare providers or insurance companies as needed.

results.ground_truth: Pre-nuptial agreements have no basis in law in Ireland. As a result, they are not strictly binding. This means that if you have a pre-nuptial agreement in place and you end up in court following the breakdown of your marriage, the judge is not bound by the terms of the pre-nuptial agreement. The only provision in Irish law is under sections 113 and 113A of the Succession Act 1965 (as amended) where a spouse or a civil partner can renounce his/her legal right share in a pre-nuptial agreement. Although they are not legally binding, there is nothing in Irish law which stops a couple planning to marry from having and signing a pre-nuptial agreement. Importantly, such agreements can serve as guides for the courts in judicial separation and divorce cases. If a pre-nuptial agreement makes ‘proper provision’ for each person it is more likely to be persuasive on the judge. Therefore, in situations where one party is likely to inherit a significant family farm or business, it will guide the judge in the divorce or judicial separation on what the parties’ intentions were at the outset.

Question: What is the legal status of pre-nuptial agreements?

Helpful Answer:
Pre-nuptial agreements, also known as pre-marital agreements, are legally recognized in many countries. These agreements are contracts entered into by two individuals before they get married. They outline how property and assets will be divided in the event of a divorce or death. The legal status of pre-nuptial agreements varies by jurisdiction, but most countries recognize them as valid contracts. In some countries, pre-nuptial agreements may be subject to certain rules or restrictions, such as requiring that both parties sign the agreement voluntarily.

results.ground_truth: The Department of Transport regulates air transport. This includes commercial and private services. EU airlines can fly freely within the EU/European Economic Area (EEA). They can do this without any restrictions on flight frequency or routes. Airlines from countries outside of the EU/EEA must request permission. They must do this each time they want to fly to, from, or over Ireland. The Department of Defence regulates military air transport in Ireland.

Question: Who regulates aviation in Ireland?

Helpful Answer:
The Air Traffic and Navigation Act 1933 and the Air Traffic and Navigation (Amendment) Act 1996 established the role of the Commission for Aviation Regulation (CAR) in regulating aviation in Ireland.

The Commission for Aviation Regulation (CAR) is the primary regulator of aviation in Ireland. CAR is responsible for regulating and overseeing the aviation industry in Ireland, including airlines, airports, and air traffic control services.

CAR's responsibilities include setting and enforcing safety standards, licensing and regulating airlines and airports, and ensuring compliance with aviation regulations. CAR also provides guidance and support to the aviation industry to ensure safe and efficient operations.

In addition to CAR, the Irish Aviation Authority (IAA) is responsible for regulating and overseeing the safety of aircraft and aircraft operators in Ireland. The IAA works closely with CAR to ensure a coordinated approach to regulating the aviation industry in Ireland.
results.answer:
The Air Traffic and Navigation Act 1933 and the Air Traffic and Navigation (Amendment) Act 1996 established the role of the Commission for Aviation Regulation (CAR) in regulating aviation in Ireland.

The Commission for Aviation Regulation (CAR) is the primary regulator of aviation in Ireland. CAR is responsible for regulating and overseeing the aviation industry in Ireland, including airlines, airports, and air traffic control services.

CAR's responsibilities include setting and enforcing safety standards, licensing and regulating airlines and airports, and ensuring compliance with aviation regulations. CAR also provides guidance and support to the aviation industry to ensure safe and efficient operations.

In addition to CAR, the Irish Aviation Authority (IAA) is responsible for regulating and overseeing the safety of aircraft and aircraft operators in Ireland. The IAA works closely with CAR to ensure a coordinated approach to regulating the aviation industry in Ireland.

results.ground_truth: Under the Cycle to Work Scheme (also known as the Bike to Work Scheme), you can get a new bike tax free through your work. Your employer pays for a new bike and then you repay the cost of regular instalments from your gross (overall) salary. You do not have to pay tax, PRSI or the Universal Social Charge on your repayments. Not every employer takes part in the scheme. However, if they do, they must offer it to all their employees. If you are self-employed, you cannot take part in the Cycle to Work Scheme unless you pay PRSI as an employee in addition to your self-employed work.

Question: What is the Cycle to Work Scheme?

Helpful Answer:
The Cycle to Work Scheme is a government initiative in the UK that allows employees to save money on their tax through a cycle to work scheme. The scheme allows employees to pay for a bicycle through monthly deductions from their salary. The employer pays a proportion of the cost of the bicycle, and the employee pays the remaining amount through their salary deductions. The scheme is designed to encourage cycling as a mode of transport. The government also provides tax relief on the scheme to make it more attractive to employees.

Key Points:
- Allows employees to pay for a bicycle through monthly deductions from their salary.
- Employer pays a proportion of the cost of the bicycle.
- Employee pays the remaining amount through salary deductions.
- Scheme encourages cycling as a mode of transport.
- Government provides tax relief on the scheme.

The scheme is designed to encourage cycling as a mode of transport. The government also provides tax relief on the scheme to make it more attractive to employees.

Key Points:
- Allows employees to pay for a bicycle through monthly deductions from their salary.
- Employer pays a proportion of the cost of the bicycle.
- Employee pays the remaining amount through salary deductions.
- Scheme encourages cycling as a mode of transport.
- Government provides tax relief on the scheme.

results.ground_truth: Operating hours vary by stop and direction of service. You can view Luas operating hours and Luas frequency on luas.ie. There are electronic displays telling you the time of the next tram at every Luas stop. In addition, there are electronic displays and announcements informing passengers of the next stop on board every tram. Special services operate during Christmas, New Year and on other occasions.

Question: What are the operating hours and frequency of the Luas?

Helpful Answer:
The Luas is Dublin's light rail system. The Luas operates on two main lines: the Luas Red Line and the Luas Green Line. The Luas Red Line operates from Tallaght to Broombridge, while the Luas Green Line operates from St Stephen's Green to Sandyford. The Luas operates Monday to Saturday from 6:00 AM to 12:00 AM. The frequency of the Luas varies depending on the line and time of day, but it generally runs every 10-15 minutes during peak hours and every 20-30 minutes during off-peak hours. The Luas operates every day of the week, including public holidays. The Luas also operates on a reduced schedule on Sundays, with some services running every 30 minutes. The Luas operates for approximately 8 hours on Sundays. 

Note: The information provided is accurate as of my knowledge cutoff date. For the most up-to-date information, please check the official Luas website or contact their customer service.
